title: Apple Explores Adding AI Search Engines to Safari
summary: Apple is looking at adding AI search engines from OpenAI, Perplexity, and Anthropic into Safari, Bloomberg reported on Wednesday. Eddy Cue, Apple’s Senior Vice President of Services, made the statement during his testimony in the U.S. Justice Department’s lawsuit against Alphabet. Cue’s disclosure was part of his testimony regarding Apple and Google’s estimated $20 billion-a-year […]
full_text_content:
Apple is looking at adding AI search engines from OpenAI, Perplexity, and Anthropic into Safari, Bloomberg reported on Wednesday.
Eddy Cue, Apple’s Senior Vice President of Services, made the statement during his testimony in the U.S. Justice Department’s lawsuit against Alphabet. Cue’s disclosure was part of his testimony regarding Apple and Google’s estimated $20 billion-a-year deal that makes Google the default search engine on Safari.
He noted that searches on Safari declined for the first time last month, a change that he attributes to the increased use of AI.
Cue also stated that he believes AI search providers will end up replacing traditional search engines like Google, which is why Apple actively looking at adding these services into its browser. However, Cue noted that these services probably won’t be the default, as he believes that they still need to improve.
Apple has already had some discussions with Perplexity, Cue said.

seo_agent_results.generated_article_body_md:
## Apple Explores Adding AI Search Engines to Safari Apple is reportedly in talks to integrate **AI search engines** from OpenAI, Perplexity, and Anthropic into Safari, according to Bloomberg. The revelation came during Eddy Cue, Apple’s Senior Vice President of Services, testimony in the U.S. Justice Department’s lawsuit against Alphabet. Cue highlighted that Safari searches declined for the first time last month, attributing the shift to the growing adoption of AI-powered alternatives. While Apple’s $20 billion-a-year deal with Google remains intact, Cue suggested that **AI search providers** could eventually replace traditional search engines. However, he noted these services may not become Safari’s default option immediately, as they still require refinement. ### The Shift Toward AI-Powered Search Apple’s exploration of AI-driven search engines marks a pivotal moment in the tech industry. With declining traditional search usage, companies like OpenAI and Perplexity are emerging as viable alternatives. Cue’s testimony underscores Apple’s proactive stance in adapting to evolving user behaviors. The potential integration could reshape Safari’s functionality, offering users more intuitive, context-aware search results. Unlike conventional search engines, **AI-powered models** leverage natural language processing to deliver precise answers rather than just links. #### Why AI Search Could Replace Google - **Enhanced User Experience:** AI models provide direct answers, reducing reliance on multiple search results. - **Declining Traditional Search:** Cue noted a drop in Safari searches, signaling shifting user preferences. - **Strategic Partnerships:** Apple’s discussions with Perplexity suggest a long-term vision for AI integration. #### Pros & Cons
Pros
- Faster, more accurate search results - Reduced dependency on traditional search engines
Cons
- AI models may lack maturity for broad adoption - Potential privacy concerns with third-party AI providers
#### Frequently Asked Questions
Will AI search engines replace Google in Safari?

While Apple is exploring AI alternatives, Google remains the default for now. AI integration may happen gradually.

Which AI search engines is Apple considering?

OpenAI, Perplexity, and Anthropic are among the candidates.
